summary: This is an FBI Daily News Briefing email from May 22, 2023, summarizing major news stories across various FBI divisions including counterterrorism, counterintelligence, criminal investigations, and other agency news. It covers a wide range of topics including FBI surveillance violations, the Durham report, various criminal cases, and international relations, with only a single, brief mention of JPMorgan and Jeffrey Epstein in a Reuters headline.

persons.name: Christopher Wray
persons.context: Mentioned in the context of House Oversight Chairman James Comer accusing the FBI under his leadership of interfering with a congressional investigation by failing to produce documents related to an alleged informant file on Joe Biden.

persons.name: James Comer
persons.context: Accused the FBI of interfering with his committee's investigation by failing to produce an FD-1023 form allegedly detailing a criminal scheme involving then-Vice President Joe Biden.

persons.name: Kevin McCarthy
persons.context: Expressed confidence that FBI Director Wray would hand over an informant file allegedly detailing President Biden's involvement in a pay-to-play scheme.

persons.name: Joe Biden
persons.context: Mentioned in the context of an alleged informant file claiming he accepted bribes while Vice President, and as the subject of debt limit talks with Republicans.

persons.name: Hunter Biden
persons.context: Reported to be under federal criminal investigation for alleged tax fraud, unregistered foreign lobbying, money laundering, and lying about drug use on a gun purchase form. His Russian associates allegedly evaded sanctions.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: Mentioned in relation to the Durham report on the FBI's Russia investigation, conflicts within his legal team, and the Georgia prosecutor's inquiry.

persons.name: Timothy Parlatore
persons.context: Publicly criticized another Trump lawyer, Boris Epshteyn, citing irreconcilable differences that led to his departure from Trump's legal team.

persons.name: Boris Epshteyn
persons.context: Accused by Timothy Parlatore of hindering the legal team's access to information and undermining efforts to defend Trump.

persons.name: John Durham
persons.context: Authored a report concluding the FBI didn't have sufficient information to open the probe into Trump's 2016 campaign ties to Russia.

persons.name: Lindsey Graham
persons.context: Commented on the Durham report, calling it 'damning' and criticizing the FBI's handling of the Steele Dossier.

persons.name: Jim Jordan
persons.context: Suggested Congress may use the 'power of the purse' to limit FBI and DOJ spending and hinted at a potential investigation into Hillary Clinton following the Durham report.

persons.name: Garret O'Boyle
persons.context: Testified before Congress, accusing the FBI of being weaponized for political gain and alleging retaliation for expressing concerns.

persons.name: Steve Friend
persons.context: Testified alongside Garret O'Boyle, alleging politicization and weaponization of the FBI.

persons.name: Jes Staley
persons.context: Mentioned in a Reuters headline regarding a court spar with JPMorgan over responsibility for Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned only in a Reuters headline regarding a court case between JPMorgan and former executive Jes Staley over responsibility for him.

connections.description: Parlatore publicly accused Epshteyn of hindering Trump's legal team's access to information and undermining their defense efforts, leading to Parlatore's departure.
Parlatore was a lawyer representing Trump in special counsel investigations before departing due to conflicts with Boris Epshteyn.
Epshteyn works as an in-house counsel for Trump, hiring lawyers and coordinating legal defense efforts.
As House Judiciary Chairman, Jordan has accused the FBI under Wray's leadership of weaponization and suggested using congressional funding power to pressure the agency.
Mentioned in the context of a court case where JPMorgan and Staley spar over responsibility for Epstein, implying a past professional or banking relationship.

events.title: FBI Surveillance Violations Revealed
events.description: A court order revealed FBI officials repeatedly violated standards when searching a foreign intelligence database for information on the Jan. 6 Capitol riot and 2020 racial justice protests.

events.title: Release of Durham Report
events.description: Special Counsel John Durham's report on the FBI's investigation into Trump's 2016 campaign ties to Russia was released, concluding the FBI lacked sufficient information to open the probe.

events.title: Conflict in Trump Legal Team Goes Public
events.description: Former Trump lawyer Timothy Parlatore went on CNN to criticize current Trump lawyer Boris Epshteyn, revealing internal conflict as the reason for his departure.

events.title: Whistleblowers Testify on FBI Weaponization
events.description: Former FBI agents Garret O'Boyle and Steve Friend testified before the House Subcommittee on Federal Government Weaponization, alleging politicization and retaliation within the FBI.

keyFacts: The document is an FBI Daily News Briefing, a routine internal/news summary, not a primary investigative document related to the Epstein case.
Jeffrey Epstein is mentioned only once, in a Reuters headline summarized in the briefing: 'JPMorgan, Ex-Executive Spar In Court Over Responsibility For Epstein'.
The briefing covers a vast array of unrelated news topics, with the Epstein reference being a minor, passing mention in a financial/legal context.
The primary focus of the document is on contemporary (May 2023) FBI-related news, including the Durham report, alleged FBI surveillance abuses, and various criminal investigations.
No substantive information about Epstein's activities, victims, or associates is contained in this document beyond the mention of a court case involving JPMorgan.
